description:
Trypanosoma conorhini is a species of protozoan parasite that belongs to the genus Trypanosoma. It is primarily found in the gastrointestinal tract of the tropical rat mite (Ornithonyssus bacoti), which serves as the vector for the transmission of the parasite.

The life cycle of T. conorhini involves two hosts: the rat mite and the rodent host, typically the brown rat (Rattus norvegicus) or the black rat (Rattus rattus). The parasite is transmitted when the infected mite feeds on the rodent host, injecting the infective stage of the parasite, known as the metacyclic trypomastigote, into the host's bloodstream.

Within the rodent host, the parasites undergo further development and differentiation, eventually transforming into the proliferative, dividing stage known as the epimastigote. These epimastigotes then migrate to the salivary glands of the mite, where they transform into the infectious metacyclic trypomastigotes, completing the life cycle.

T. conorhini is primarily of interest in the field of comparative parasitology, as it provides insights into the evolution and adaptation of trypanosomes to different host-vector systems. Additionally, the study of this parasite can contribute to a better understanding of the ecology and epidemiology of vector-borne diseases affecting rodent populations.
